\begin{center}
{ \LARGE \textbf{Generalized Gravitational Entropy for WAdS$_3$ }\\}
\vspace*{1.7cm}
Wei Song, Qiang Wen and Jianfei Xu\\
\vspace*{0.6cm}

Yau Mathematical Sciences Center\\
Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China\\

\begin{abstract}
\noindent
For spacetimes which are not asymptotic to AdS (non-AAdS), we adapt the Lewkowycz-Maldaceda procedure to find the holographic entanglement entropy. The key observation, which to our knowledge has not been very well appreciated, is that asymptotic boundary conditions play an essential role on extending the replica trick to the bulk.
For non-AAdS, we expect the following three main modifications: 1. The expansion near the special surface has to be compatible with the asymptotic expansion.  2. Periodic conditions are imposed to coordinates on the phase space with diagonalized symplectic structure, not to all fields appearing in the action. 3. Evaluating the entanglement functional using the boundary term method amounts to evaluate the presymplectic structure at the special surface, where some additional exact form may contribute.
Explicit calculation is carried out for three dimensional Warped Anti-de Sitter spacetime (WAdS$_3$) in a consistent truncation of string theory, the so-called self-dual dipole theory. It turns out that the generalized gravitational entropy  in WAdS$_3$ is captured by the least action of a charged particle in WAdS$_3$ space, or equivalently, by the geodesic length in an auxiliary AdS$_3$. Consequently, the bulk calculation agrees with the CFT results, providing another piece of evidence for the WAdS$_3$/CFT$_2$ correspondence.



\end{abstract}

\section{Introduction}
Entanglement plays a central role in many fields of physics, including many body systems, quantum information, and quantum field theories.
In the context of AdS/CFT \cite{Maldacena:1997re,Gubser:1998bc,Witten:1998qj}, Ryu and Takayanagi \cite{Ryu:2006bv,Ryu:2006ef}  proposed that the holographic dual of the entanglement entropy is captured by the area of a minimal co-dimension two surface in the bulk. A covariant version was proposed in \cite{Hubeny:2007xt}. Large amount of evidence \cite{Nishioka:2009un} have accumulated and an explanation as the generalized gravitational entropy was made by Lewkowycz and Maldacena \cite{Lewkowycz:2013nqa}.

On the other hand, the success of holography goes beyond AdS/CFT,  for instance, the recent development of the  Kerr/CFT correspondence \cite{Guica:2008mu,Bredberg:2011hp}, flat space holography \cite{Barnich:2010eb}, Shr\"{o}dinger or Lifshitz spacetime/non-relativistic field theory duality \cite{Son:2008ye, Balasubramanian:2008dm}, etc.
Some efforts \cite{Li:2010dr,  Anninos:2013nja, Gentle:2015cfp} have been made in understanding the holographic entanglement entropy in these spacetimes without an asymptotic AdS boundary (non-AAdS). However, naively using the minimal area prescription leads to some puzzles.

One of the simplest type of non-AAdS spacetime is the so-called Warped AdS$_3$ (WAdS$_3$) spacetime, which appears in various contexts of physics, including three dimensional gravity \cite{Vuorio:1985ta},  extremal Kerr black holes \cite{Guica:2008mu,Bredberg:2009pv}, and cold atom systems \cite{Son:2008ye}.
It was noticed \cite{Anninos:2008fx} that the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy of WAdS$_3$ black holes can be rewritten in the form of Cardy Formula of a two dimensional conformal field theory (CFT$_2$). Hence it was conjectured that WAdS$_3$ is holographically dual to a CFT$_2$ \footnote{There is some evidence that the dual theory is the so-called dipole-CFT \cite{ElShowk:2011cm, Song:2011sr}, the IR limit of dipole deformed 2D gauge theory. The area law of the black hole entropy suggests that the  high-energy density of states of dipole-CFT is independent of the deformation parameter. In this paper, CFT refer to both ordinary CFT and dipole-CFTs. }. Based on some earlier efforts \cite{ElShowk:2011cm, Song:2011sr, Guica:2011ia,Guica:2013jza}, the boundary conditions in support of this conjecture was found out \cite{Compere:2014bia}. Hereafter, we refer to this set of boundary conditions as the Dirichlet boundary conditions.
Alternatively, under the Dirichlet-Newmann boundary conditions \cite{Compere:2009zj, Compere:2013bya}, WAdS$_3$ was conjectured to be dual to the so-called WCFT featured by a Virasoro-Kac-Moody structure \cite{Hofman:2011zj}, with the evidence that the black hole entropy can also be interpreted as the DHH \cite{Detournay:2012pc} formula in WCFT, an analog of Cardy Formula.

In this letter, we take the approach of the generalized gravitational entropy \`{a} la Lewkowycz and Maldacena \cite{Lewkowycz:2013nqa}, and give a prescription of holographic entanglement entropy for non-AAdS spacetime.
The key observation is that asymptotic boundary conditions play an essential role in order to extend the replica symmetry to the bulk.
As a consequence, the dual of the entanglement entropy is not necessarily given by the minimal area (length) in the bulk spacetime we start with.
For non-AAdS, we expect the following three main modifications to the Lewkowycz-Maldacena prescription:
\begin{itemize}
\item The expansion near the special surface should be compatible with the asymptotic expansion.
\item Periodic conditions should be imposed to coordinates on the phase space with diagonalized symplectic structure, not to all fields appearing in the action.
\item Evaluating the entanglement functional using the boundary term method amounts to evaluate the presymplectic structure at the special surface. The ambiguity in the presymplectic structure, which is fixed by requiring holography to work, could contribute to the final result.
\end{itemize}

As an example, we  explicitly worked out the holographic entanglement entropy for WAdS$_3$ with Dirichlet boundary conditions. Interestingly, the holographic entanglement entropy is given by the least action of a charged particle in WAdS$_3$, or equivalently, by the geodesic length in some auxiliary AdS$_3$. Consequently, the bulk calculation agrees with the CFT results, providing another piece of evidence for the WAdS$_3$/CFT$_2$ correspondence under the Dirichlet boundary conditions.
It will be interesting to apply our prescription to the Dirichlet-Neumann boundary conditions and find out if the bulk calculation agrees with the field theory calculation \cite{Castro:2015csg}.
It will also be very interesting to explore the range of validity of the RT proposal. \cite{Lewkowycz:2013nqa} proves it for Einstein gravity in the context of AdS/CFT.
Corrections are expected if the bulk theory is not Einstein gravity \cite{Dong:2013qoa, Castro:2014tta}. While our analysis shows that there are also corrections due to the effect of non-AAdS.

This paper is organized as follows. In section \ref{section B} we demonstrate why and how the Lewkowycz-Maldacena prescription is modified for non-AAdS spacetimes.  In section \ref{section C} we review the self-dual dipole theory and the Dirichlet boundary conditions for WAdS$_3$. In section \ref{section D} we apply the prescription in section \ref{section B} to WAdS$_3$, and find out the holographic entanglement entropy. In section \ref{section E} we further interpret the result as the least action of a charged particle in WAdS$_3$.

\section{ Generalized gravitational entropy for non-AdS spacetimes}\label{section B}
When a holographic duality exists for a non-AdS spacetime,  we adapt the prescription of Lewkowycz and Maldacena \cite{Lewkowycz:2013nqa} to derive the bulk dual of entanglement entropy.

The key assumptions and steps are as follows.

\subsection{Holographic duality}\label{subsec i}
Our first assumption is the existence of holographic duality for non-AAdS spacetime, and  the compatibility of different formalisms to establish the duality. For a given non-AAdS background,  {\it consistent boundary conditions} have to be imposed in order to define the bulk gravitational theory, and furthermore to find out the holographic dual.
In the prescription \cite{Gubser:1998bc,Witten:1998qj}, specifying the boundary condition of a bulk field
is to identify the boundary value of the field
as the source of the dual operator.

However, ambiguity in separating the source from the vev may appear \cite{vanRees:2012cw}.
As was argued in \cite{Guica:2013jza}, a proper way is to read the source and vev from the symplectic form.

Schematically, we consider the asymptotic expansion of the metric \footnote{The explicit formulae  (\ref{bc}) applies directly for WAdS$_3$, as we will show later. For more general non-AAdS spacetimes,   (\ref{bc}) should be replaced by the appropriate consistent asymptotic expansion.},
\begin{eqnarray}
ds^2&=&ds_0^2+warping\,,\label{bc}\\
ds_0^2&=&\sigma^{-2}(d\sigma^2+\gamma^{(0)}_{ij}dx^i dx^j)+h_{\mu\nu}dx^\mu dx^\nu\,,\label{bct}
\end{eqnarray}
where $\sigma$ parameterizes the radial direction with the asymptotic boundary at $\sigma\rightarrow 0$.
$\gamma^{(0)}_{ij}$ is the source of the dual stress tensor, and therefore is identified with
the metric of the dual field theory.  $h_{\mu\nu}$ includes all subleading terms in the small $\sigma$ expansion.
The \textit{warping} terms do not source the stress tensor, but are not necessarily subleading. Note that asymptotic AdS spacetimes does not contain \textit{warping} terms.
Similarly,
the boundary expansion for all other fields, collectively denoted by $\phi_i$, gives a prescription of reading the sources $\phi_i|_{source}$ that coupled to the dual operators. Conversely, to find out the bulk dual of any operator at the boundary, we have to find the bulk configuration by specifying the boundary values of the source $\phi_i|_{source}$.
In many examples of holography for non-AAdS \cite{Guica:2008mu, Barnich:2010eb, Compere:2014bia}, asymptotic symmetry analysis gives some indication about the dual field theory.

There are various methods of asymptotic symmetry group analysis, with subtleties appearing in different aspects.

In the holographic renormalization formalism,  appropriate boundary terms need to be found, such that the variation of the renormalized action
$S_{rn}=S+S_{bn}$ does not contain any contributions from the asymptotic boundary for all variations obeying the chosen boundary conditions.
At the classical level, the partition function of the field theory is then approximated by the renormalized on-shell action $S_{rn}$ on a classical bulk solution.
For a systematic description of this approach, see \cite{deBoer:1999tgo,deHaro:2000vlm,Skenderis:2002wp}.
In the covariant phase space formalism \cite{Barnich:2001jy,Barnich:2007bf}, there are ambiguities in deriving the presymplectic structure and symplectic structure, which will furthermore lead to some ambiguities in the definition of conserved charges.
We assume that the covariant formalism and the holographic renormalization analysis are compatible with each other, namely, correctly fixing these ambiguities in the the covariant approach should lead to a consistent identification of the source/vev, as well as appropriate boundary terms in the holographic renormalization approach.
A consistent set of boundary conditions and a prescription of the conserved charges are the key ingredients to find out the asymptotic symmetry group.


In the following, we will switch languages between the two formalisms.


 

\subsection{Replica trick on the boundary} \label{subsec ii}
Consider a quantum field theory on a manifold $\mathcal{N}$, the entanglement entropy can be calculated by the replica trick,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{VNEZ}
S_{EE}({\mathcal{A}})&=&-n{\partial}_n[\log \mathcal{Z}_n-n\log \mathcal{Z}_1]|_{n=1}\,,
\end{eqnarray}
where $\mathcal{Z}_n$ is the partition function on some manifold $\mathcal{N}_n$. The manifold $\mathcal{N}_n$ is the n-fold cover of $\mathcal{N}_1$, defined by first making $n$ copies of $\mathcal{N}_1\equiv \mathcal{N}$, cutting each $\mathcal{N}_1$ open at a region ${\mathcal{A}}$, and then gluing them together cyclically. By construction, there is a $Z_n$ symmetry whose set of fixed points is the boundary of region ${\mathcal{A}}$ denoted by $\partial {\mathcal{A}}$.


 


For a field theory with Lorentzian invariance, let $\tau$ denotes the angle around ${\partial} {\mathcal{A}}$. Then on ${\mathcal{N}}_n$,
 all fields have the property $\phi^B_{i}(\tau)=\phi^B_i(\tau+2\pi)$, but with period $\tau\sim \tau+2\pi n$.
For conformal field theory, the most divergent piece of the entanglement entropy is universal \cite{Srednicki:1993im}. Recently,  some universal results \cite{Castro:2015csg} have also be derived for the so-called Warped  Conformal Field Theory (WCFT) featured by Virasoro-Kac-Moody symmetry \cite{Hofman:2011zj,Detournay:2012pc}.
In that case, we should start from a modified replica trick on the boundary, and modify some details in the following two steps accordingly.


\subsection{Selecting a curve in the bulk} \label{subsec iii}
Let ${\mathcal{M}}_n$ denote the bulk extension of ${\mathcal{N}}_n$. Then the relation between data on ${\mathcal{N}}_n$ and data on ${\mathcal{M}}_n$ should be read from the asymptotic expansion (\ref{bct}). $\gamma_{ij}^{(0)}$ appearing in the bulk metric is identified with the metric on ${\mathcal{N}}_n$.
The metric of ${\mathcal{M}}_1$ near a co-dimension two surface ending on ${\partial}{\mathcal{A}}$ can be expanded as
{\begin{eqnarray}
ds^2&=&ds_{e}^2+tilting\,,\label{nc}\\
ds_e^2&=&dr^2+r^2 d\tau^2+(\tilde{g}_{ij}+ 2K_{aij}x^a)dy^idy^j

+subleading\,,\label{nct}\end{eqnarray}
where 
 $r$ parameterizes the separation from the curve \footnote{For $n=1$, we can first write the expansion in Lorentiaz signature $
ds^2= \big(-(dx^0)^2+(dx^1)^2\big)+\cdots$,  Wick rotate $x^0=ix^2$, and then go to the polar coordinate system.  }. The \textit{tilting} terms are added to make $\tau$ the bulk extension of  the circle around ${\partial}{\mathcal{A}}$.
In other words, {\it the first modification to Lewkowycz-Maldacena is, the asymptotic expansion (\ref{bc}) at small $\sigma$ and the near curve expansion (\ref{nc}) at small $r$ have to be compatible with each other. }Namely, after some coordinate transformations,
the leading terms in (\ref{bc}) and (\ref{nc}) agree with each other at the double limit $\sigma\rightarrow 0$ and $ r \rightarrow 0$, \begin{eqnarray}
ds^2_0|_{r\rightarrow 0}&=& ds^2_e|_{\sigma\rightarrow 0}\,,\label{matchingf}\\
warping|_{r\rightarrow0} &= & tilting|_{\sigma\rightarrow 0}\,,\label{matching}\\
 \phi_i|_{source}(\tau)&=&\phi_i^B(\tau)\,.
 \end{eqnarray}
With (\ref{bc}), (\ref{nc}) and (\ref{matchingf}) in mind, we can extend the replica symmetry to the bulk following the reasoning of \cite{Lewkowycz:2013nqa}.
Let  ${\mathcal{C}}_n$ denotes the set of the fixed points of $Z_n$. The expansion near ${\mathcal{C}}_n$ is then
\begin{eqnarray}
ds^2&=&ds_{e,n}^2+tilting\,,\label{ncn}\\
ds_{e,n}^2&=&n^2dr^2+r^2 d\tau^2+(\tilde{g}_{ij}+2K^{(n)}_{aij}x^a)dy^idy^j

+subleading\,.\label{nctn}
\end{eqnarray}
In order to select a special co-dimension two surface, we need to impose some regularity condition of the fields near ${\mathcal{C}}_n$. In \cite{Lewkowycz:2013nqa}, the requirement is that all fields and their variations are periodic. However, this condition could be overdetermining when there are mixings between various fields, as in our example later. As we mentioned before, the matching between the bulk and the boundary is through the source/vev relation, or equivalently, through the symplectic structure. Note that in the covariant formalism, the symplectic structure can be defined in the bulk \cite{Compere:2014bia}. Therefore, {\it we propose the second modification to Lewkowycz-Maldacena: to impose periodicity condition for all the independent coordinates on the phase space, and their variations}. In particular,

WAdS$_3$ is a classical solution with constant $U$.
In the following we will focus on the sector with fixed $U$, which is to turn off all propagating modes.
In the calculation of holographic entanglement entropy, this is to assume that the hairless classical solution with replica symmetry is the dominant contribution to the Renyi entropy  \footnote {Some of these propagating modes discussed in section 4.1 of \cite{Compere:2014bia} may become dangerous tachyons in the large $n$ limit, as was noticed in \cite {Belin:2013dva}. However, it was also argued  in \cite {Belin:2013dva} that with Dirichlet boundary conditions, the dominant saddle is still hair-less solution around $n=1$. Therefore the entanglement entropy is not affected. }, at least for $n$ slightly greater than $1$.


 
 
 
 
 



In terms of an auxiliary metric $\tilde{g}_{\mu\nu}$ and field $\tilde{A}_{\mu}$ given by
\begin{eqnarray}\label{bridge}
\tilde{g}_{\mu\nu}&=&e^{-4U}g_{\mu\nu}+A_{\mu}A_{\nu}\,,\\
\tilde{A}_{\mu}&=&A_{\mu},  \tilde{A}^{\mu}=\tilde{g}^{\mu\nu}\tilde{A}_{\nu}=A^{\mu}\,,\end{eqnarray}
the equations of motion of the sector with fixed $U$ can be written as
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{eq3}
&&\tilde{R}_{\mu\nu}+\frac{2}{\ell^2}\tilde{g}_{\mu\nu}=0\,,\\
&&\tilde{F}_{\mu\nu}=\frac{2}{\ell}\tilde{\epsilon}_{\mu\nu\lambda}\tilde{A}^{\lambda}\,,
\,
\tilde{A}^{2}=1-e^{-4U}\,.\label{eq4}
\end{eqnarray}
with ${A}$ being a Killing vector in both $\tilde{g}$ and $g$,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{eq5}
\nabla _{(\mu}A_{\nu)}=
\tilde{\nabla}_{(\mu}\tilde{A}_{\nu)}=0\,.\end{eqnarray}
(\ref{eq3}) is just the equations of motion of the three-dimensional Einstein gravity with a negative cosmological constant $-{1\over\ell^2}$, which means that $\tilde{g}$ is locally $AdS_3$.
(\ref{eq4})-(\ref{eq5}) define a self-dual Killing vector $\tilde{A}$ with constant norm.
On the other hand,
given a locally AdS$_3$ solution $\tilde{g}$,  and a self-dual Killing vector $\tilde{A}$ with constant norm, then (\ref{bridge}) uniquely defines a solution of self-dual dipole theory. In particular, the metric $g_{\mu\nu}=e^{4U}(\tilde{g}_{\mu\nu}-\tilde{A}_\mu\tilde{A}_\nu)$ is then locally WAdS$_3$ by definition. 









\subsection{The WAdS$_3$/CFT$_2$ correspondence}\label{subsec C2}
A Dirichlet type of boundary conditions in support of the WAdS$_3$/CFT$_2$ conjecture \cite{Anninos:2008fx} was found in \cite{Compere:2014bia}.
In the sector without bulk propagating modes, $U$ is a fixed constant, the boundary conditions can be written as
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{bcwads}{ds^2\over\ell^2}&=&(1-\chi)^{-1}\big(d{\tilde s}^2-A^2\big)\,,\\
{{A}\over\ell}&=&\chi e^\Phi dt^+-\Big({e^{-\Phi}\over2}\sigma^{-2}+{\chi e^\Phi L \over 2k }\sigma^2\Big)dt^-\,,\\
{d\tilde{s}^2\over\ell^2}&=&{d\sigma^2-dt^+dt^-\over\sigma^2}-{\chi e^{2\Phi}L\over k }\sigma^2dt^+dt^-+{L\over k}(dt^-)^2
\nonumber\\
&&
+\Big({1\over4}({\partial}_+\Phi)^2+\chi e^{2\Phi}\Big)(dt^+)^2+{{\partial}_+\Phi\over\sigma}d\sigma dt^+,\label{bcads}\end{eqnarray}
where $\chi=1-e^{-4U}$ is a constant, $\Phi=\Phi(t^+)$ and $L=L(t^-)$.
For the WAdS$_3$ black string solution, both $\Phi$ and $L$ are constant.
Note that this asymptotic expansion terminates, and  (\ref{bcwads}) is the full non-linear solution of the S-dual dipole theory with $U$ fixed.

The dual
field theory is then defined on a fixed two dimensional Minkovski space
prevtext:
where $S_{1}$ is the $\tau$ circle.
So, after we integrate out $\tau$, the entanglement entropy is just given by a surface integral on $\gamma_\mathcal{A}$.

Note that most of the discussions are general, although we used some explicit expressions for some special examples in order to illustrate the idea.

\section {Generalized gravitational entropy for WAdS$_3$} \label{section D}
Following the  outline in section \ref{section B}, now we try to find the holographic entanglement entropy for WAdS$_3$.
At this point, we only focus on the classical contribution.
Section {\ref{subsec C2}} describes how holography works for WAdS$_3$, and gives all the information we need for section {\ref{subsec i}}.
Under the boundary condition (\ref{bcwads}), and the choice of the presymplectic structure (\ref{Y}), the conjectured dual field theory for WAdS$_3$
has two Virasoro symmetries, and can be approximated by a CFT.
Following section \ref{subsec ii},  we assume a standard replica trick for the CFT, as the universal part of the entanglement entropy only depends on the central charge.
Section \ref{subsec iii} is to extend the replica trick to the bulk. We need to write down a near curve ansatz which is compatible with the boundary condition (\ref{bcwads}). We assume that the dominant saddle for $n$ slightly greater than $1$ is the classical black string solution, which means the propagating modes are turned off, or equivalently $U$ is fixed. The AdS$_3$ metric $d\tilde{s}^2$ with Dirichlet boundary conditions can be written in the form of (\ref{nctn}).
Due to relation (\ref{bridge}),  a natural ansatz for $ds^2$ is then to set

Effectively, this means that we expand $g$ by expanding the auxiliary metric $\tilde{g}$ in the form of (\ref{nct}) without tilting,
\begin{eqnarray}
ds^2&=&e^{4U}(d\tilde{s}^2-A^2)\\
 d\tilde{s}^2&=&n^2dr^2+r^2 d\tau^2+(\tilde{g}_{yy}+2K^{(n)}_{ayy}x^a)dy^2+subleading\,. \label{stnc}\
\end{eqnarray}
For $n=1,$ there is a local coordinate transformation between (\ref{stnc}) and (\ref{bcads}), which determines the expansion of $A$ as well.
For small $n-1$, $\delta_n g$ and $\delta_n A$ should satisfy the linearized equations, which means that $\delta_n {\tilde g}$ and $\delta_n \tilde{A}$ satisfy the linearized form of (\ref{eq3}) and (\ref{eq4}). Note that at the fixed $U$ sector, $\tilde{A}$ is not dynamical,  and hence does not correspond to a source. Thus we do not set any periodicity condition to $\tilde A$ independently.  On the other hand, $\delta_n \tilde{g}$ appears in the symplectic form, which means that we should impose the periodicity condition to the trace of the extrinsic curvature,

Plugging the anstz (\ref{stnca}) and regularity condition (\ref{rga}) into the linearized version of Einstein equation (\ref{eq3}),
the $n$-th solution with a conical defect in $d\tilde{s}^2$ is given by
\begin{eqnarray}\label{hatg}
d\tilde{s}^2&=&\left[n^2+\mathcal{O}( r^2)\right]dr^2 +\left[r^2+\mathcal{O}( r^4)\right]dt^2
 +\mathcal{O}( r^2)~dt dy+\mathcal{O}( r^2) ~dr dy\cr
&&+\left[f(y,n)+\mathcal{O}( r^2)\right]dy^2\,.
\end{eqnarray}
  As a gauge choice, we set $f(y,1)=1$. A general ansatz for the vector field ${A}_{\mu}$ with finite norm can be written as
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="K_{a}(\tau)=K_{a}(\tau+2\pi),\delta_{n}K_{a}(\tau)=\delta_{n}K_{a}(\tau+2\pi)\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>τ</mi><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

Plugging into (\ref{eq4})-(\ref{eq5}), we get

\begin{eqnarray}\label{as}
\partial_\tau a_y(y,\tau,0,n)&=&0 \,,
\\
a_y(y,\tau,0,n)^2&=&1-\alpha (y,n)^2-\beta (y,n)^2-e^{-4 U}\,,
\nonumber\\
a_\tau(y,\tau,0,n)&=&\cos \left(\frac{\tau}{n}\right) \alpha (y,n)+\sin \left(\frac{\tau}{n}\right) \beta (y,n)\,,


\nonumber\\
a_r(y,\tau,0,n)&=&n \big[\sin \left(\frac{\tau}{n}\right) \alpha (y,n)-\cos \left(\frac{\tau}{n}\right) \beta (y,n)\big]\,.\nonumber


\end{eqnarray}

Note that  $\delta_n A_\mu(\tau)\neq \delta_n A_\mu(\tau+2\pi)$.  As we argued in the main text, we do not impose periodicity condition on $\delta_n A$, since it does not show up in the symplectic structure. As we will see more explicitly later,  the on-shell action is independent of $\tau$, which makes sure that $S_{E}[{\mathcal{M}}_n]=nS_{E}[\hat{{\mathcal{M}}}_n]$.
Plugging (\ref{stnca}) and (\ref{as}) into the holographic entanglement entropy
$
S_{EE}=\partial_nS_{E}[\hat{\mathcal{M}}_n]\big|_{n\to 1}
$, it is straight forward to see that the contribution only comes from boundary terms, which is captured by the presymplectic structure
\cite{Compere:2014bia},
\begin{eqnarray}\label{theta}\Theta^{\mu}_{g}&=&g^{\mu\nu}g^{\rho\sigma}\nabla_{\rho}\delta_ng_{\sigma\nu}-g^{\mu\nu}g^{\rho\sigma}\nabla_{\nu}\delta_ng_{\rho\sigma}\,,
\\
\Theta^{\mu}_{A}&=&-\frac{2}{\ell}\epsilon^{\mu\nu\rho}A_{\rho}\delta_{n}A_{\nu}\,,\nonumber
\\
\Theta^{\mu}_{Y}&=&-\nabla_{\nu}(A^{\mu}\delta_{n}A^{\nu}-A^{\nu}\delta_{n}A^{\mu})\,.\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
Plugging (\ref{stnca}) and (\ref{as}) into (\ref{theta}) we get

which is just the result (\ref{See3}) we calculated from the auxiliary AdS$_3$. In general $g_{yy}|_{n\to 1, r\to 0}$ is not $1$ under this gauge, therefore $\widetilde {Length}({\gamma}_\mathcal{A})$ is not the length of $\gamma_A$ evaluated using $g$.
